title: Part A

descriptions: The response does not identify the number of trout (per kilometer) older than 1 year upstream of the dam in 2011 as 360.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe the relationship between the installation of the fish ladder and the number of trout (per kilometer) older than 1 year upstream of the dam, such as any of the following:

· After the installation of the fish ladder, the number of trout older than 1 year increased upstream of the dam.

· The fish ladder allowed the older trout to bypass the dam, increasing their population size.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain why the number of species that lay eggs in the sediment decreased the year after dam removal, such as any of the following:

· The dam removal eliminated or reduced habitat for the eggs when the river flow changed/the scouring from the new water flow disrupted the stream bed.

· The dam removal disrupted the stream bed habitat that was previously downstream of the dam and the species did not have sediment to lay eggs in.

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one sustainable approach for the grazing of poultry chickens, such as any of the following:

· Shift chickens to different portions of a field to allow time for fields to fallow.

· Allow chickens to roam in open areas rather than confining them in small pens.

· Reduce the number of animals grazing/herd size.

· Free range grazing allows waste from chickens to naturally fertilize the soil, leading to less need for synthetic fertilizer.

· Chickens allowed to free range will not require antibiotic use, lessening chances of the development of antibiotic resistant bacterial strains.

· Controlled/Rotational grazing of poultry on different pastures to avoid overgrazing/desertification or erosion.

The response describes one sustainable approach for the grazing of poultry chickens, such as one of the following:

· Shift chickens to different portions of a field to allow time for fields to fallow.

· Allow chickens to roam in open areas rather than confining them in small pens.

· Reduce the number of animals grazing/herd size.

· Free range grazing allows waste from chickens to naturally fertilize the soil, leading to less need for synthetic fertilizer.

· Chickens allowed to free range will not require antibiotic use, lessening chances of the development of antibiotic resistant bacterial strains.

· Controlled/Rotational grazing of poultry on different pastures to avoid overgrazing/desertification or erosion.

title: Part H
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one environmental problem that semiarid areas may experience, because of the increased need for agricultural land for beef production, such as any of the following:

· Increased desertification/erosion due to overgrazing on land that has little precipitation.

· Increased aquifer depletion/surface water decrease due to water needed to irrigate feed crop fields.

· Increased need for irrigation water could lead to soil salinization.

The response describes one environmental problem that semiarid areas may experience, because of the increased need for agricultural land for beef production, such as one of the following:

· Increased desertification/erosion due to overgrazing on land that has little precipitation.
